Example: 'Her smile was as bright as the sun'
Makes a comparison with a linking word
Giving human qualities or actions to inanimate objects or animals

Makes non-human things seem alive

A rhetorical device for dramatic effect

Can be described as gloomy, cheerful, or suspenseful

Can be formal, informal, serious, or humorous

Like a paragraph in a poem
A division of a poem's lines

A figure of speech where a speaker directly addresses something or someone who is not present

Example: a play where the villain ties the heroine to the train tracks
The beginning of a story where characters, setting, and background are introduced
Provides essential information for the reader
Part of the plot structure
The most intense, exciting, or important point of a story
The turning point of the narrative
The high point of a plot
The part of a literary plot that occurs after the climax has been reached
The tension decreases
Leads to the resolution
The end of a story where the conflict is resolved
The final outcome of the plot
Follows the falling action
The final part of a play, film, or narrative in which the strands of the plot are drawn together
The final part of a story, similar to resolution
French term for the 'untying'
The sequence of events in a story
Includes the exposition, rising action, climax, falling action, and resolution
The narrative arc of a work
The struggle between two opposing forces in a story
Can be internal (character vs. self) or external (character vs. nature)
Creates tension and drives the plot
A spoken or written account of connected events
The telling of a story
A description of events
The time and place in which a story occurs
Can include the physical environment and the social context
Helps to create mood and atmosphere
A conversation between two or more characters in a literary work
Moves the plot forward and develops characters
What characters say to each other
A thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists
Example: a knight using a smartphone in a medieval story
Something out of its proper time
A figure of speech in which an opposition or contrast of ideas is expressed
Example: 'Speech is silver, but silence is gold'
Puts opposing ideas together
The omission or absence of a conjunction between parts of a sentence
Example: 'I came, I saw, I conquered'
Creates a sense of urgency and speed
The use of several conjunctions in close succession
The opposite of asyndeton
Example: 'And Joshua, and all of Israel... and the tabernacles...'
A figure of speech in which a word applies to two others in different senses
Example: 'He lost his coat and his temper'
A word that links two different things
A figure of speech in which one sense is described using terms from another sense
Example: 'a loud shirt' or 'a sweet sound'
Mixing senses
The mistaken use of a word in place of a similar-sounding one
Often with unintentionally amusing effect
Example: 'He is the very pineapple of politeness'
An idea or feeling that a word invokes in addition to its literal meaning
The implied or suggested meaning of a word
Differs from denotation
The literal or primary meaning of a word
The dictionary definition of a word
Differs from connotation
Intended to teach, particularly in having moral instruction as an ulterior motive
Having a teaching purpose
A didactic piece of literature
Overly concerned with minute details or formalisms, especially in teaching
Characterized by a narrow, academic focus
Someone who is overly scholarly
A short quotation or saying at the beginning of a book or chapter
Often serves to suggest the theme of the work
A brief motto
A separate introductory section of a literary or musical work
Gives a preview of what is to come
Introduces the story
A section or speech at the end of a book or play that serves as a comment on or a conclusion to what has happened
A postscript to a story
Tells what happens after the main story ends
A short and amusing or interesting story about a real incident or person
Used to illustrate a point
A personal story
A historical account or biography written from personal knowledge or special sources
Focuses on a specific period or event in the author's life
A type of autobiography
An account of someone's life written by someone else
A life story
A non-fiction genre
An account of a person's life written by that person
A life story written by oneself
Example: 'The Diary of Anne Frank'
A form of deductive reasoning consisting of a major premise, a minor premise, and a conclusion
Example: All men are mortal; Socrates is a man; therefore, Socrates is mortal
A three-part argument
The quality of being pleasing to the ear through a harmonious combination of words
Flowing and musical language
A pleasant sound
A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds
The opposite of euphony
Uses harsh consonants and sounds
A typical example or pattern of something
A conceptual model
A way of looking at the world
The appearance of being true or real
The quality of a story that makes it seem believable
How realistic a literary work seems
Of such excellence, grandeur, or beauty as to inspire great admiration or awe
Beyond ordinary experience
A literary concept of greatness
A school of thought in philosophy and literature
Explores the idea that human existence is without meaning or purpose
Example: 'Waiting for Godot'
A philosophical theory or approach that emphasizes the existence of the individual as a free and responsible agent determining their own development
Focuses on freedom, choice, and responsibility
Example: Jean-Paul Sartre
A literary movement characterized by skepticism, irony, and the rejection of grand narratives
Often includes metafiction and intertextuality
A modern literary movement
An unexpected power or event saving a seemingly hopeless situation
Latin for 'god from the machine'
A plot device that feels artificial
A fatal flaw leading to the downfall of a tragic hero or heroine
A Greek term for a character's mistake
A tragic flaw
Excessive pride or self-confidence
Often a tragic flaw that leads to a character's downfall
A common trait in Greek heroes
Insulting, abusive, or highly critical language
Uses strong, negative words
A type of verbal attack
A compound metaphorical expression used in Old English and Norse poetry
A two-word phrase to describe something simply
Example: 'battle-sweat' for blood
A metrical foot consisting of two unstressed syllables followed by one stressed syllable
Example: 'da-da-DUM'
A three-syllable foot
A metrical foot consisting of one stressed syllable followed by two unstressed syllables
Example: 'DUM-da-da'
A three-syllable foot
A metrical foot consisting of two stressed syllables
Example: 'BREAK-FAST'
Used for emphasis
The basic rhythmic structure of a verse or line in poetry
The pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables
The systematic arrangement of rhythm
The pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables in a line of poetry
The beat or flow of a poem
Provides a musical quality
Repetition of vowel sounds in nearby words
Example: 'Go slow over the road'
A sound device similar to alliteration
Repetition of consonant sounds within or at the end of words
Example: 'Pitter Patter'
A sound device similar to alliteration and assonance
Repetition of consonant sounds at the beginning of words
Example: 'Peter Piper picked a peck...'
A sound device in poetry
A word that imitates the natural sounds of a thing
Example: 'buzz,' 'hiss,' 'boom'
Words that are sounds
The repetition of similar sounding words, occurring at the end of lines in poems
Example: 'bright' and 'night'
A musical device in poetry
A rhyme in which the vowels or consonants of stressed syllables are identical
Also known as 'near rhyme' or 'half rhyme'
Words that are similar in sound but do not rhyme perfectly
A rhyme involving a word in the middle of a line and another at the end of the line or in the middle of the next
Creates a musical effect within a single line or stanza
Not just at the end of lines
Two lines of verse, usually in the same meter and joined by rhyme
A pair of rhyming lines
Often ends a Shakespearean sonnet
A stanza of four lines, especially one having a rhyme scheme
A four-line poetic unit
Often found in poems
A stanza of six lines
Often used in sonnets
A six-line stanza
A verse form consisting of eight lines of iambic pentameter
The first eight lines of a Petrarchan sonnet
An eight-line stanza
A group of lines forming the basic recurring metrical unit in a poem
Like a paragraph in a poem
A division of a poem's lines
The continuation of a sentence without a pause beyond the end of a line, couplet, or stanza
Also known as a 'run-on' line
Creates a sense of flow in poetry
Verse without rhyme, especially that which uses iambic pentameter
A form of poetry often used by Shakespeare
Has a meter but no rhyme
Poetry that does not rhyme or have a regular meter
Follows the rhythm of natural speech
A modern form of poetry
A short quotation or saying at the beginning of a book or chapter
Often serves to suggest the theme of the work
A brief motto
A separate introductory section of a literary or musical work
Gives a preview of what is to come
Introduces the story
A section or speech at the end of a book or play that serves as a comment on or a conclusion to what has happened
A postscript to a story
Tells what happens after the main story ends
A short and amusing or interesting story about a real incident or person
Used to illustrate a point
A personal story
A historical account or biography written from personal knowledge or special sources
Focuses on a specific period or event in the author's life
A type of autobiography
An account of someone's life written by someone else
A life story
A non-fiction genre
An account of a person's life written by that person
A life story written by oneself
Example: 'The Diary of Anne Frank'
An artistic work in a style that imitates that of another work, artist, or period
An imitation or tribute
Differs from a parody because it does not mock
